text:
Description: 
  When shutting down a Jmeter running in server mode from a Jmeter client in 
GUI mode the server does not shut down the rmi registry.

Initial setup: 
1. Install JMeter on 2 machines.
2. In the properties file of 1 of the machines add to the remote_hosts property 
the second machine.
3. Start the machine that you registered as a remote host as ./jmeter-server 
(Server Mode) and the other as ./jmeter (GUI mode) .

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. With the GUI use the command run->Remote Exit All. Though I belive that this 
will probably end up with the same result if I use the Remote Exit and choose a 
host. 
2. Login to the machine that was in server mode and do a ps -ef | grep rmi.

Actual Results:
The rmiregistry in which JMeter started is still running.

Expected Results:
When JMeter exits it should clean up it's processes.

Note:
I am not sure if the OS and Platform is relavant but this was done on a Solaris 
machine. I do not have the time or resources to check this out on other 
platforms.
creator: danderson_75@yahoo.com

text: Why not to start RMI registry in-process?
creator: vasiliy.gagin@gmail.com
sebb@apache.org
text:
As suggested (so long ago!), the registry is now started in-process.

So when JMeter exits, the rmi registry will be shut down.
